Line 31: Line 31:
===Overview===
===Overview===
{{main|History of Syria}}
{{main|History of Syria}}
  +
[[File:Rifaathafezassad.jpg|thumb|right|180px|Former President [[Hafez al-Assad]] (right), and his brother [[Rifaat al-Assad]] (left), who personally supervised the [[Hama massacre]].]]
Syria has been under Emergency Law since 1962, effectively suspending most [[constitutional]] protections for citizens. Syrian governments have justified the [[state of emergency]] by pointing to the fact that Syria is in a state of war with [[Israel]]. Syrian citizens approve the President in a [[referendum]]. Syria does not hold [[multi-party elections]] for its legislature.<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite web|url=http://www.state.gov/r/pa/ei/bgn/3580.htm |title=Syria (05/07) |publisher=State.gov |date=|accessdate=25 October 2008}}</ref>
Syria has been under Emergency Law since 1962, effectively suspending most [[constitutional]] protections for citizens. Syrian governments have justified the [[state of emergency]] by pointing to the fact that Syria is in a state of war with [[Israel]]. Syrian citizens approve the President in a [[referendum]]. Syria does not hold [[multi-party elections]] for its legislature.<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite web|url=http://www.state.gov/r/pa/ei/bgn/3580.htm |title=Syria (05/07) |publisher=State.gov |date=|accessdate=25 October 2008}}</ref>
Line 36: Line 37:
After the [[1970 Syrian Corrective Revolution|1970 Revolution]], President [[Hafez al-Assad]] led Syria for just short of 30 years, banning any opposing political party and any opposition candidate in any election.
After the [[1970 Syrian Corrective Revolution|1970 Revolution]], President [[Hafez al-Assad]] led Syria for just short of 30 years, banning any opposing political party and any opposition candidate in any election.
â
[[File:Rifaathafezassad.jpg|thumb|right|180px|Former President [[Hafez al-Assad]] (right), and his brother [[Rifaat al-Assad]] (left), who personally supervised the [[Hama massacre]].]]
 
In 1982, at the climax of a six-year [[Islam]]ic insurgency throughout the country, President Hafez al-Assad conducted a [[scorched earth]] policy against the town of [[Hama]] to quell a revolt by the [[Sunni Muslim]] community, including the [[Muslim Brotherhood]] and others. Tens of thousands of people, including 10â80,000 civilians, were killed in the [[Hama massacre]].<ref name="autogenerated5"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.meforum.org/683/syrian-reform-what-lies-beneath |first=Farid N.|last=Ghadry|title=Syrian Reform: What Lies Beneath |date=Winter 2005 |publisher=The Middle East Quarterly }}</ref><ref name="The Sturdy House That Assad Built">{{cite web|url=http://www.foreignaffairs.com/articles/67561/michael-broening/the-sturdy-house-that-assad-built|title=The Sturdy House That Assad Built |date= 7 March 2011 |author=Michael BrÃ¶ning |publisher=The Foreign Affairs}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/27/world/middleeast/27diplomacy.html|title=Chaos in Syria and Jordan Alarms U.S.|author=Mark Landler|work=New York Times|date=26 March 2011|publisher=New York Times}}</ref><ref>''Robert Fisk: Freedom, democracy and human rights in Syria'', ''The Independent'', Thursday, 16 September 2010</ref><ref name="GlobalSecurity">{{cite web|url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/wmd/world/syria/hama.htm |title=Hama |publisher=GlobalSecurity.org| accessdate=14 November 2009}}</ref>
In 1982, at the climax of a six-year [[Islam]]ic insurgency throughout the country, President Hafez al-Assad conducted a [[scorched earth]] policy against the town of [[Hama]] to quell a revolt by the [[Sunni Muslim]] community, including the [[Muslim Brotherhood]] and others. Tens of thousands of people, including 10â80,000 civilians, were killed in the [[Hama massacre]].<ref name="autogenerated5"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.meforum.org/683/syrian-reform-what-lies-beneath |first=Farid N.|last=Ghadry|title=Syrian Reform: What Lies Beneath |date=Winter 2005 |publisher=The Middle East Quarterly }}</ref><ref name="The Sturdy House That Assad Built">{{cite web|url=http://www.foreignaffairs.com/articles/67561/michael-broening/the-sturdy-house-that-assad-built|title=The Sturdy House That Assad Built |date= 7 March 2011 |author=Michael BrÃ¶ning |publisher=The Foreign Affairs}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/27/world/middleeast/27diplomacy.html|title=Chaos in Syria and Jordan Alarms U.S.|author=Mark Landler|work=New York Times|date=26 March 2011|publisher=New York Times}}</ref><ref>''Robert Fisk: Freedom, democracy and human rights in Syria'', ''The Independent'', Thursday, 16 September 2010</ref><ref name="GlobalSecurity">{{cite web|url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/wmd/world/syria/hama.htm |title=Hama |publisher=GlobalSecurity.org| accessdate=14 November 2009}}</ref>
Line 44: Line 44:
===2011===
===2011===
â
[[File:Syria.BasharAlAssad.jpg|thumb| left| 155px| [[Bashar al-Assad]]]]
+
[[File:Syria.BasharAlAssad.jpg|thumb|right|155px|[[Bashar al-Assad]].]]
While Bashar al-Assad had permitted existence of radio stations playing Western [[pop music]], websites such as [[Wikipedia]], [[Youtube]], [[Facebook]], and [[Amazon.com|Amazon]] were blocked until 1 January 2011, when all citizens were permitted to sign up for [[high speed internet]], and those sites were allowed.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.economist.com/node/11792330 |title=Red lines that cannot be crossed â The authorities donât want you to read or see too much |date=24 July 2008 |work=The Economist }}</ref> However, a 2007 law requires [[Internet cafe]]s to record all comments that users post on [[online chat]] forums.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://en.rsf.org/predator-bashar-al-assad,37213.html |title=Bashar Al-Assad, President, Syria |publisher=Reporters Without Borders }}</ref>
While Bashar al-Assad had permitted existence of radio stations playing Western [[pop music]], websites such as [[Wikipedia]], [[Youtube]], [[Facebook]], and [[Amazon.com|Amazon]] were blocked until 1 January 2011, when all citizens were permitted to sign up for [[high speed internet]], and those sites were allowed.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.economist.com/node/11792330 |title=Red lines that cannot be crossed â The authorities donât want you to read or see too much |date=24 July 2008 |work=The Economist }}</ref> However, a 2007 law requires [[Internet cafe]]s to record all comments that users post on [[online chat]] forums.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://en.rsf.org/predator-bashar-al-assad,37213.html |title=Bashar Al-Assad, President, Syria |publisher=Reporters Without Borders }}</ref>
